sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: This is Euronews Tonight. Here are your top stories.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Russian Foreign Minister Sergei Lavrov continues his tour of Africa, telling leaders his country is not to blame for a food shortage despite a months-long Russian blockade of Ukrainian ports.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Myanmar carries out its first executions in decades, killing four pro-democracy activists and sparking international condemnation.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: No glass without gas. Europe's glassmakers and other key industries react to an EU proposal to cut gas use by 15% amid an energy crisis.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: And here in the Cube, we'll unpack the growing dispute between France and the UK after thousands of drivers were stuck in the port of Dover this weekend.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: I'm Helena Humphrey. It is good to have you with us. Russian Foreign Minister Sergei Lavrov

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: is on a four-day tour of Africa looking to rally support for Moscow and reassure its allies on the continent that it's committed to protecting the global food supply. But after Russia's missile attack on the Ukrainian port city of Odessa on Saturday, Lavrov has so far spent much of the trip allaying concerns over last week's deal to lift a blockade on grain exports from Ukraine. Speaking to reporters in the Republic of Congo, Lavrov said that the strike didn't violate the terms of the agreement. The episode that you mentioned that took place in Odessa, there is nothing in the liabilities Russia undertook, including under the agreement signed on July 22nd in Istanbul, that can bar us from continuing this special military operation, and hitting military infrastructure and other military targets.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: Well, for more on this, we can bring in Samuel Romani now.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: He's an associate fellow at the Royal United Services Institute.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: He's also an author of the book, What Now for Russia in Africa.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Samuel, welcome. Good to have you back with us.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: I'm going to quote the title of your book then in this question, What Now for Russia in Africa? Samuel, welcome. Good to have you back with us. I'm going to quote the title of your book then in this question.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: What now for Russia in Africa?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: What exactly is Foreign Minister Sergei Lavrov looking to achieve with this visit?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: Well, I think that Sergei Lavrov wants to show that Russia's power projection in the global south has not been affected by the Ukraine war.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: And he's emphasising the foreign policy independence of African countries, which means that they're not complying with the Western sanctions regimes.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: And he's also wanting to reassure his African partners that, one, Western sanctions are not going to prevent megaprojects like oil pipelines and nuclear energy projects from getting off the ground.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: And second, that Russia's still a reliable purveyor of grain and agricultural products to African countries.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: You mentioned there reassurance.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: That's something he's probably had to do quite a bit of.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: African nations will have seen the strike on Odessa over the weekend, shortly after that grain export deal was signed.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Realistically, how quickly can we expect that grain to get out of those ports?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: So Ukraine says that the grain could be exported from those ports by the end of the week.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: And they've actually laid out a potential logistical route that could make it happen.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: Odessa is only one of three ports that Ukraine can use, and only one of two in southwestern Ukraine.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: Tornomorsk will probably be the first one that could be activated, maybe even by the middle of this week.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: So the Ukrainians are pretty optimistic that the Odessa port strike is a hiccup, but not a game changer when it comes to implementing the deal.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: We know that Russia will be looking for allies,

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: or at least to strengthen existing partnerships in Africa.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: I mean, African nations themselves have not joined in with Western sanctions against Russia.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: But do you think that they will be looking to get any closer to Moscow during this particular visit? Well, I think it's possible that many African countries could be getting closer to Russia. I mean, I think Egypt is going to consolidate its existing projects, like the El Daba nuclear reactor, the Suez Canal industrial zone project. None of those seem to be impacted by Western sanctions, at least right now, because Rosatom isn't sanctioned.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: Ethiopia wants to get closer to Russia because of Russia's favorable position on the Tigray War.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: And Russia views Uganda as a vital entry point to East Africa, and Congo as a potential connectivity point to its power projection in the Central African Republic.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: So I think that there's a lot of opportunities for Russia to develop and grow its relationships in Africa. And the countries that Lavrov has picked are especially suitable for that. All right, Sam, you'll stay with us because I want to update our viewers with the

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: latest developments on the ground right now in Ukraine and then come back to you because what we're seeing is Ukrainian forces saying that they have destroyed 50 Russian ammunition depots, effectively cutting off the Kremlin's logistics. Now, Kyiv says it is confident that it will retake the southern region of Kherson by September. Back over then to Samuel Romani. Samuel, of course, you just heard there, you'll be aware of the fact that Ukrainian forces are saying that they are now hoping to continue to launch a counter-offensive and retake Kherson.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Do you think that aim is within their grasp? I think that that's certainly within their grasp.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: I think that the Ukrainians could launch an effective counter-offensive, but there's also some reasons to be a bit sceptical of the September deadline that Ukraine seems to have put forward.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: Number one, even though the Himars are quite effective in removing Russian ammunition depots, they still only have 12 of them, and the Ukrainians believe that they need 50 from the United States in order to successfully prosecute a counteroffensive of this kind. It's unclear whether the Biden administration is going to part with so many systems. Secondly, Russia's artillery advantage is still very pronounced. I've been seeing anecdotal reports on the ground, the AFP, for example, talking about how Russia's got a 6 to 1 to 8 to 1 advantage in terms of artillery. And that's something that Ukraine can't really overcome easily. And third, Russia has already built up an entrenched defensive fortification and infrastructure in Karzhan.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: And being the attacking force is a lot harder than being on the defensive. So those are three reasons why I think it's possible Ukraine can gain real momentum, but maybe not by September. So it is nevertheless

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: difficult, as you've just outlined there. But strategically, how could retaking Kherson actually change the fight in the south as well as access to the Black Sea?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: Well, retaking Kherson would be a major game changer for the Ukrainians, because it would also severely limit Russia's ability to project power on the Dnipro River.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: And that's why the Russians were so nervous when the Ukrainians were striking the Adomovsky Bridge, for example, because that would leave their forces stranded there, it would disrupt their supply routes in Donbass.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: It would be a pretty significant blow.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: And that's why I think that the Russians might pull something of a surprise referendum between now and September to ensure that Curzon enters Russia's territory and makes any attack on Ukraine a de facto attack on Russia. And that will complicate potentially even Western arms supplies and Western military assistance. So Russia could do some unpredictable things because of Curzon's importance. It felt that Curzon was at risk. All right right Samuel Romani from the Royal United Services Institute as ever great

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: to have your analysis thanks Samuel. Thank you. Well the battle is still raging in Donetsk in the east of the country and it's not safe there for civilians but many people who previously fled the area are returning due to a lack of options and financial need. Glynis Croke has more.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_12
sentences.sentence: It's dangerous, but they can't afford to stay away.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_12
sentences.sentence: Tens of thousands of people who were evacuated from Ukraine's eastern Donetsk region are returning to their homes close to the front line.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_12
sentences.sentence: But it's not safe.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_12
sentences.sentence: Despite the fact that many houses are ruined and the bombing continues, officials in the region estimate that 70% of evacuees have come back.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: They gave us food. We had everything in the evacuation, but it was temporary. But then they told us to go to a nursing home. My son refused.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: Having no money was a big problem for those who were evacuated. It was difficult to find work, but you still need to pay rent.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_12
sentences.sentence: Better, they say, to be at home.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_12
sentences.sentence: 18-year-old Karina is her family's main breadwinner.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_12
sentences.sentence: I understand that it's very risky to stay here in town, but if we leave, nobody waits for us there.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11
sentences.sentence: Who will take care of us? We need to earn money.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11
sentences.sentence: The funeral of 35-year-old Anna Protzenko, who tried living elsewhere but returned to take a job in her hometown Prokrovsk.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_12
sentences.sentence: She was killed two days later.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11
sentences.sentence: On Monday, friends and family wept at her graveside.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_12
sentences.sentence: Glynis Kruk, Euronews.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Myanmar has carried out four executions, a first for the country in a decade.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: The hangings of a democracy activist, a former lawyer and two prisoners accused of conspiring to commit acts of terror has sparked international outrage.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Our reporter Mark Armstrong has more on the story.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: Myanmar's military junta says it carried out the first executions in the country for nearly 50 years with the hanging of four prisoners.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: They included two democracy activists, Kyaw Min-yoo, also known as Ko Jimmy, and former lawmaker Mong Kyaw, who was a member of ousted leader Aung San Suu Kyi's party.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: They were accused of conspiring to commit acts of terror after the country's military takeover last year.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: The executions, announced on Monday, were carried out despite worldwide pleas for clemency.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: The organization Human Rights Watch called the executions a sign of depravity.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: The Mirror Daily state newspaper said the four were hanged according to prison procedures, but did not say when the executions occurred.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: Myanmar's foreign ministry rejected any criticism over the hangings declaring that the country's judicial system is fair. Tunisians are voting in a controversial referendum that could see

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: their leader President Kays Saeed handed near total power. Saeed called to the vote on the first anniversary of Tunisia's 2021 political crisis that saw the president suspend parliament and rule by decree.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Mario Boden has more.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: Tunisians head to the polls today for a referendum called by President Saeed.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: The head of state is suggesting changes to the constitution which would transfer powers from the prime minister to the President.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: The date of the referendum is exactly one year after President Said dismissed the government and froze Parliament.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: Since then, critics of the President have grown louder, but divisions among the opposition have hampered the ability to form a clear stance against Said.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: But over the weekend, Tunisians took to the streets to demonstrate against today's vote, which they see as a coup attempt and a return to a pre-2011 dictatorship.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: Public enthusiasm is low for the referendum, but tensions are high, with Tunisians more concerned with the looming economic crisis.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: Well, Pope Francis has begun a week-long tour of Canada where he's visiting indigenous communities to apologize for the abuses that took place for more than half a century in mostly church-run residential schools.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Catholic missionaries are accused of trying to forcibly assimilate generations of native children.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Last year, suspected unmarked graves of children were found on the grounds of a school in British Columbia.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: However, the country's indigenous communities are seeking more than just an apology.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: They're also demanding reparations, access to archives to discover what happened to missing children and the return of artefacts held by the Vatican museums.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Firefighters have made good headway against a wildfire burning through areas around Yosemite

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: National Park in California.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: More than 2,500 firefighters were deployed to the site after the fire erupted on Friday.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: By Sunday night, it had burned through 63 square kilometers of forest.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: It had also destroyed at least 10 buildings and damaged five others and forced the evacuation of around 6,000 people. Well, climate change is fueling fires along the United States' west coast as the area has steadily gotten warmer and drier. Moscow has charged 92

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: members of Ukraine's armed forces with crimes against humanity, according to the head of the country's investigative committee.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Another 96 people, including 51 commanders, are currently wanted by Russian forces.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: In total, 1,300 criminal investigations have begun.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: That's according to an interview by Alexander Bastrykin in the state-run newspaper Raskaja Gazeta.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: However, independent media has not been able to verify the claims.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: The news comes after 40 countries, including the United States, have agreed to coordinate investigations into alleged war crimes in Ukraine, the majority of which have been attributed to Russian forces.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: We'll have plenty more to come after a short break.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Do stay with us if you can.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: You're watching Euronews tonight. Welcome back.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Ahead of an EU energy minister's meeting on Tuesday, Russian energy giant Gazprom has announced a reduction in gas deliveries to Europe via the Nord Stream 1 pipeline.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Gazprom says that gas supplies will be cut by 50% to 33 million cubic metres from Wednesday, blaming problems with a turbine.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Well, the news comes as the EU scrambles to look for gas-saving solutions over fears of a total cut-off from Moscow.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: The latest proposals would see member states cutting consumption by 15%, but some countries, including Spain, Portugal and Greece, have hit back at the proposed target, saying that one sweeping number for the whole block is unfair.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: For more on this, we can bring in our correspondent Shona Murray, who is in Brussels for us.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Shona, countries, industries, they've all been weighing this idea of reducing gas consumption by 15%.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: How's it going down?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: Well, as you mentioned there, there's a real concern from some countries, particularly southern countries like Greece, Portugal, Spain, that the one size fits all 15% reduction in demand for every country, that that's not suitable because each country has different energy mixes. Many are less reliant on gas, in particular, very much less reliant on Russian gas. So they're kind of pointing the finger at Germany, saying, well, you've sort of been over-dependent on Russian gas.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: Why should we have to reduce our gas consumption on that basis?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: And that's also, some of the Baltic countries are saying that as well.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: The other issue that they have is, while this 15% reduction is voluntary initially, it can become mandatory if there's a severe shortage of gas, and the Commission can trigger that. Some countries are saying that it shouldn shortage of gas and the Commission can trigger that.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: Some countries are saying that it shouldn't be down to the Commission to do that.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: It should be the member states.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: So there's a sort of a meeting going on from all around all EU ambassadors to try to prepare some sort of agreement for energy ministers who are coming to Brussels tomorrow and then finally sign off on this because obviously it's something that is needed. Now earlier on today I caught up with expert Simone Tagliapietra who I asked really about his assessment about this plan from the Commission and generally speaking the EU's proposals and sanction packages for the past several months.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: We even didn't want to discuss a gas embargo while at the same time now is Russia fundamentally putting an embargo on Europe on gas because the flows have been cut by two-thirds.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: So we are now down to very low volumes of Russian gas coming into Europe and that has been a Russian decision not a European. So I think that in this strategic game of sanctions, Europe has not played a very strategic game. It could have played a better game, for example, by imposing a tariff on the Russian oil and gas, as it was suggested by many in March, but politically that was not possible. So I think that now Europe what needs to do is to make itself resilient from the gas perspective. That's now the key emergency, the key issue to be tackled and that can only be done by reducing the gas demand. So that's why this package is very important because reduction of gas demand is the key item that Europe now should pursue in order to avoid Putin energy blackmail in the winter.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: And as we heard there from Simone, Helena, the EU really needs to make itself resilient because of Russia's weaponising of gas like we saw today.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: because of Russia's weaponizing of gas like we saw today.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: It needs to make itself resilient, but there's also quite some resistance, which brings me to the question, could that essentially undermine European unity when it comes to showing support for the war in Ukraine?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: And are there any alternative proposals here?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: Well, it's really interesting because at the top you mentioned Vladimir Putin's decision to halt another turbine from Nord Stream 1, which will reduce by half again the supply of gas coming into Germany.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: It was already at 40% capacity. Now it's going to be at 20% capacity.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: So the worst fears of what Brussels and EU member states look to be materialising, that Vladimir Putin is weaponising energy.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: So I think that will provide the impetus to ensure that that solidarity and unity remains, even though, of course, European member states are going to be very jittery about the impact that these sanctions are having on their own economies.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: But at the same time, which is reiterated all along, is that the important thing is that solidarity remains with Ukraine and Vladimir Putin and Russia can't be victorious in this war because the greatest picture is, of course, European democracy. Helena?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Shona Murray there reporting from Brussels. As ever, good to talk to you, Shona. Thanks a lot.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Well, thousands of holiday goers and freight drivers were left stuck in queues this weekend at the English port of Dover, sparking a war of words between Britain and France.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: And now both sides are blaming each other for the gridlock.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Well, our team in the Cube has been looking into this with Sophia.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: Well, Helena, it was quite a horrific start to the holiday season for thousands of travellers as well as truck drivers in the UK.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: Thousands of cars were at a standstill and some people have said to have waited up to six hours to catch their ferries.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: Now, this disruption has created a new dispute between France and the UK, with, for example, British Foreign Secretary Liz Trust who is currently campaigning to succeed Prime Minister Boris Johnson who very quickly blamed France. The fact is the French authorities have not put enough people on the border she said during a campaign rally in Kent this Saturday.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: And the Port of Dover also accused the French authorities of staffing shortages, tweeting that the resources this weekend were woefully inadequate.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: Now, these accusations were swiftly denied by French politicians who blamed Brexit for the delays.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: Clément Bonne, the French transport minister, tweeted that France is not responsible for Brexit.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: And Pierre-Henri Dumont, who is a right-wing MP whose constituency includes Calais, tweeted that this was all an aftermath of Brexit. And it's true that since Britain left the EU in 2020, UK travellers have faced stricter and longer controls in order to enter Europe. And today's traffic may have returned to normal. But Helena British and French authorities are really going to have to work together in the next coming days to ensure that this does not happen again because next weekend is the second busiest of the holiday season. Very important point to make there Sofia and team thank you so much. Well still to come the host of Eurovision 2023 is the UK on behalf of this year's winner, Ukraine.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: We'll explain how it'll work after the break.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Welcome back. Good to have you with us.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: Now, Ukrainian rap group Kalush Orchestra's stunning performance at this year's Eurovision Song Contest helped their war-torn country earn the right to host next year's competition but the security situation has made that impossible as Tom Bolton reports as the 2022 winners it would be Ukraine's turn to host next year's Eurovision contest but because of Russia's invasion of the country Britain which came second has agreed to host the annual competition in its place. Organisers said the security conditions were not right for Ukraine to be the host.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: We will be in the United Kingdom. We will have BBC as the host broadcaster, but we will also, of course, do a lot of things to honour our winner, Ukraine, and our member organisation, UAPBC, in Ukraine. So we'll have a lot of I think Ukrainian flavor if you like and Ukrainian talents on display. As this year's winner Ukraine automatically qualifies for the 2023 grand final and work is underway to find a host city and a venue in Britain, with Scotland's biggest city, Glasgow, regarded as the bookmaker's favourite. Tom Bolton, Euronews.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: We leave you with a no comment from Senegal, where hundreds of locals are piling onto longboard wooden canoes for the annual San Luis regatta. Thanks for watching Euronews tonight.....
